questions.question: In the context of pushdown automata, what is the main purpose of the stack?

answers.b: To store intermediate results during computation.

explanations.b: Correct! The stack in a pushdown automaton is used to store intermediate results during computation.

questions.question: What distinguishes a pushdown automaton (PDA) from a finite automaton (FA)?

answers.a: The PDA has an infinite tape.
answers.b: The PDA has a stack for additional memory.
answers.c: The PDA can recognize non-regular languages.
answers.d: The PDA uses transition rules instead of states.

explanations.b: Correct! A key distinction is that a PDA has a stack for additional memory, unlike a finite automaton.

questions.question: How does the construction of a pushdown automaton (PDA) differ from that of a finite automaton (FA) when recognizing languages?

answers.a: PDAs are only constructed for regular languages, while FAs can recognize context-free languages.
answers.b: PDAs use a stack for additional memory, enabling recognition of context-free languages.
answers.c: PDAs have fewer states compared to FAs for the same language.
answers.d: The construction process is identical for both PDAs and FAs.

explanations.b: Correct! PDAs use a stack for additional memory, allowing them to recognize context-free languages.
